description: A traditional Hyderabadi layered rice and chicken dish made with aromatic spices, herbs, and fried onions, slow-cooked to perfection using the dum method.

main: 1 kg chicken thighs (skin off, preferably on the bone)
A pinch of saffron (or 1/4 tsp turmeric as substitute)
spices: 2 tsp Kashmiri chili powder (or regular chili powder)
1 cinnamon stick (split between rice and marinade)
1 tsp cumin seeds (for rice and marinade)
for_sealing_dough: Water (as needed to make a firm dough)

kitchen_tools_and_dishes: Large deep pot with lid (for biryani cooking)
Tray or plate lined with paper towels (for fried onions)
Mandolin or sharp knife (for slicing onions)
Slotted spoon (for removing onions from oil)
Serving platter or large tray (for plating biryani)

steps.instruction: Thinly slice a large quantity of onions using a knife or mandolin.
Heat 2 cm of vegetable oil in a pan over medium-low heat.
Fry the onions in batches until golden and crisp, stirring constantly to avoid burning.
Remove onions just before fully browned and place on paper towels to cool.
Repeat frying with remaining onions.

Combine chicken thighs with yogurt, chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, ginger paste, garlic, lemon juice, sliced green chilies, cinnamon stick, crushed cardamom pods, cumin seeds, cloves, and salt.
Add chopped mint, coriander, and one-third of the fried onions to the chicken mixture and mix well.
Cover and marinate chicken in the fridge for at least 4 hours (up to 24 hours).
Wash and rinse aged basmati rice twice, then soak it in water for 35–40 minutes.
Warm milk and steep saffron strands in it to create saffron milk (or use turmeric as a substitute).
Prepare sealing dough by mixing flour and water into a workable dough and rolling it into a long log; let it rest.
Boil water in a large pot, add salt, cardamom, green chili, cinnamon stick, cloves, and cumin seeds.
Drain soaked rice and add it to the boiling water; cook until just al dente (4–5 minutes).
Drain the rice immediately to prevent overcooking.
Heat marinated chicken on high heat for 4–5 minutes to start cooking; stir frequently.
Remove half of the chicken and set aside for layering.
Layer the remaining chicken evenly in the pot, followed by a layer of cooked rice.
Add the reserved chicken pieces, remaining sauce, fried onions, coriander, and mint on top.
Top with the final layer of rice, more onions, herbs, and pour saffron milk evenly over it.
Seal the pot tightly with the prepared dough or a clean tea towel under the lid.
Cook the sealed pot on high heat for 10 minutes, then reduce to low heat and cook for 30 minutes.
Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest for 20 minutes before opening.
Break the dough seal carefully, mix lightly, and serve the biryani layered with herbs and onions.

serving_suggestion: Serve hot on a large platter, garnished with fresh coriander, mint, and crispy onions. Pair with raita or salad.
notes: Use aged basmati rice for distinct, non-sticky grains.
Marinate chicken for at least 4 hours for best flavor.
Do not overcook rice before layering; it will finish cooking during the dum process.
If saffron is unavailable, use turmeric for color and aroma.
